options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I got a great introduction to cryptography, access control, malware, and software.

I learned a lot about cryptography and computer security. A lot of my knowledge was in depth but nothing overbearing and I really appreciate the thought put into lectures along with the amazing guest lecturers we had.
Definitely learned a lot more about security, hackers, etc.
I learned a good deal about crypto, access control and protocols. The topics were all pretty interesting, I especially enjoyed learning about networks and protocols.
I was introduced to a wide range of security concepts that tied directly to real-world scenarios. A lot of the course was thinking about ways that security can be compromised.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The course was very well-designed and the slides/lectures/book line up perfectly. I would have loved to see some content beyond the book materials though, although the guest speaker were great.
Guest lectures and teachers presentation of the material were great. Sometimes hard to give 100% focus over zoom but not necessarily the professors fault.
The textbook and lectures were both really good. If anything, I feel like a project instead of an essay would have been really cool.

The course is extremely well organized. I think this is both a strength and a weakness. The slides and each lecture are almost word for word the same as reading the textbook, so I think lecture could be more interesting if it broke away from that a little more. The guest lecturers were definitely a strength, it was very cool to hear from them about current events in information security.

The best parts of the course were the guest speakers and the case study. The concepts that we learned were definitely connected to real-world events, but the guest speakers and case study help to solidify some of those concepts.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: as good as it could be given the circumstances
The homeworks succeeded. There really werent any other practices.
Recorded lectures were super helpful since I had a couple of time/schedule conflicts with work.
It of course would have been better to be in person, but I think the class was extremely well run remotely.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would highly recommend this course to anyone, not only CS majors, who are interested in computer security. The class is somewhat technical and some coding knowlede is required, but it is quite minimal.
Yes phenomenal course to understand a little more than the basics of the subjects covered in this course.

I loved this course! The textbook is super comprehensive and the problem sets were really fun. Some of them involved writing mini Python scripts and were super helpful in understanding topics from the book.

I think the course is pretty interesting, and the workload is not very hefty. You get a nice introduction into some topics not covered in other cs courses that I know of and the guest lectures are very cool. I'd recommend it to another person, CS or not.
I would recommend this course to anyone interested in security. There are a lot of topics covered, and it might get very boring for someone who does not have an interest in it.
